Answer:
It can also be called teaching before, referring to teaching sentient beings about the Buddha's merits, teaching the ten great precepts, and even teaching the three great vows.
But the previous praise of the Buddha's merits was not called teaching;

Within the expounding of the Dharma, there are ten chapters of sÅ«tra, which are broadly divided into two parts:

The first is the tenth acceptance, which clarifies the acceptance of the true Dharma to prevent false loss;
Next, the third vow clarifies the acceptance of the true Dharma, abandoning body, life, and wealth to rescue and protect it;
The third chapter on the vow of accepting the true Dharma clarifies that all vows are the same as one vow, namely accepting the true Dharma;
The fourth chapter on the practice of accepting the true Dharma clarifies that the meaning of accepting the true Dharma is vast.
Although the name is marked in four places, it is still not understood, and it is explained here.
As for acceptance, if wisdom realizes the principle, and the principle gives rise to wisdom, then it is the two views of object and wisdom, and it is not called acceptance.
If the subject and object are both obscure, and object and wisdom are both tranquil, then it is called accepting the true Dharma.
This is the great school of the Buddha Dharma, the deep repository of realization and awakening.
Moreover, there is this text coming, the wisdom realizing the principle has the meaning of non-duality and duality, and the meaning of duality and non-duality.
The meaning of non-duality and duality is that wisdom is the ability to realize, and principle is what is realized. Principle is the ability to give rise to, and wisdom is what is given rise to.

The meaning of duality and non-duality is not seeing wisdom as the ability to illuminate, and principle as what is illuminated. Principle is the ability to give rise to, and wisdom is what is given rise to.
As the MahÄprajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ ÅšÄstra says, Conjoined with prajÃ±Ä, yet not seeing what is conjoined and what is not conjoined.
Being conjoined with prajÃ±Ä is the meaning of non-duality and duality;
Not seeing what is conjoined and what is not conjoined is the meaning of duality and non-duality.
The MahÄprajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ ÅšÄstra says, The true aspect is not prajÃ±Ä, but is able to give rise to prajÃ±Ä.
This is the meaning of non-duality and duality.
It also says, Conditions are one side, and contemplation is one side. Although they are two sides, they are called the middle way.
This is the meaning of duality and non-duality.
From above, it clarifies the acceptance of the true Dharma, clarifying the meaning of non-duality and duality;
Now it clarifies the mutual identity, which is the meaning of the non-duality of the two.
Moreover, if discussing it in terms of stages, bodhisattvas below the grounds have not yet realized the truth, so the object and wisdom are still two;
Those who have ascended the grounds and above accord with the truth, and the contemplation of conditions is both tranquil.

If discussing it in terms of eliminating afflictions, when the assembly hears about the acceptance of the true Dharma, they may think that wisdom is the acceptor and the true Dharma is what is accepted, thus giving rise to the two views of object and wisdom;
Now, in order to eliminate the two views, it clarifies non-duality, and thus this text comes about.
These four points of meaning penetrate the following and cannot be omitted.
World-Honored One, accepting the true Dharma - this one sentence brings up the previous words about accepting the true Dharma.
The meaning of vastness has already been explained above, but the acceptance of the true Dharma has not yet been explained. Now, wanting to explain it, it is brought up again.
Embracing the true Dharma clarifies the meaning of embracing.

In order to explain it, the chapter heading is restated.ğŸ”½No difference from the true Dharma clarifies that embracing is precisely the true Dharma, meaning that wisdom is no different from the object.
No difference from the true Dharma that is embraced clarifies that the true Dharma is no different from wisdom.
The true Dharma is precisely the true Dharma that is embraced, directly concluding that principle is no different from wisdom.
Because of non-duality, it is said to be no difference, not because of similarity that it is said to be no difference.
The World-Honored One is no different from the pÄramitÄs - from above, the chapter on vastness has been explained, and now the second chapter on immeasurable causal practices is explained.
Because principle gives rise to practice, practice is explained after principle.
Moreover, the term true Dharma is general, not only principle is the true Dharma, practice is also the true Dharma, therefore, this text comes.
In the text, there are also two parts:
First, clarifying embracing, next, clarifying the true Dharma.
The previous section first clarified the true Dharma and then clarified the acceptance, while now the former clarifies the acceptance and the latter clarifies the true Dharma.
The reason it is different from the previous is because it connects the acceptance from above and clarifies the acceptance.
Moreover, the acceptance and the true Dharma have no sequence in meaning, so they can be explained in reverse.
Moreover, it wants to clarify the meaning of the introduction, explanation, and conclusion, which is why it first clarifies the acceptance.
As for the introduction, explanation, and conclusion, the initial introduction is the meaning;
from why is it so below, the explanation is the meaning;
next, this later conclusion is the meaning.

Herein, it should clarify the section on explaining the name.ğŸ”½As for what is said to be accepting the true Dharma, the six pÄramitÄs are precisely the causal practices of the true Dharma.ğŸ”½Recording the Dharma of the six pÄramitÄs in the mind is called accepting;
because one suddenly realizes according to the Dharma of the six pÄramitÄs, it is called receiving.

At the time of sudden realization, one does not see the includer, the included, the realizing, or the realized. Not knowing what to call it, one provisionally names it inclusion. This is precisely the meaning of the mutual identity of characteristics that is being explained now.
Moreover, inclusion has the meaning of non-duality and duality, and the meaning of duality and non-duality.
Because it is non-dual yet dual, there is the includer, the included, the realizing, and the realized;
Because it is dual yet non-dual, the subject and object are distinct yet always quiescent.
Moreover, if explained in terms of stages, those below the grounds have not yet attained true realization, and thus there is still subject and object;
Those who have ascended to the grounds and above have permanently attained true realization, and thus both the object and the contemplation are quiescent.
If eliminating afflictions, sentient beings consider the includer and the included to be different;
In order to eliminate those two views, it is explained that they are non-dual.
This is eliminating duality to explain non-duality. Once the two afflictions are gone, non-duality is also removed.
As the Huayan says, Do not cling to the non-dual Dharma, because there is neither one nor two.
The MahÄprajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ ÅšÄstra says, Destroying duality and not grasping at unity is called the acceptance of the Dharma.
The acceptance of the Dharma means the mind is at ease with the principle of the Dharma, and does not see one or two.
In the text there are two parts:
First, generally clarifying non-duality; next, specifically clarifying non-duality; third, concluding by summarizing non-duality.
The first part has three sentences.ğŸ”½There is no difference between pÄramitÄ clarifies that the acceptance of the true Dharma is no different from pÄramitÄ.
There is no difference between pÄramitÄ and the acceptance of the true Dharma clarifies that pÄramitÄ is no different from the acceptance of the true Dharma.
Question:
How is this different from the above acceptance?
Answer:

There are similarities and differences.ğŸ”½If it is said that the acceptance is no different from pÄramitÄ, and pÄramitÄ is no different from the acceptance, then this is the same as the above principle of wisdom being no different from the Dharma, and the Dharma being no different from wisdom.

But above it clarified that the Dharma is no different from wisdom, and wisdom is no different from the Dharma. Now it clarifies that wisdom is no different from practice, and practice is no different from wisdom.

If it is said that the acceptance of the true Dharma is no different from the perfections, and the perfections are no different from the acceptance of the true Dharma, this is to clarify the meaning of the vastness of the acceptance of the true Dharma.

It is not only the true Dharma of principle that is the acceptance of the true Dharma, the practices of the perfections are also the acceptance of the true Dharma, and therefore the meaning of the acceptance of the true Dharma is vast.

The acceptance of the true Dharma is precisely the perfections - the previous two sentences clarify that there is no difference, and now the third sentence concludes by distinguishing that there is no difference.
The reason there is no difference is because they are precisely the same, and therefore it is said that there is no difference, not because they are similar that it is said there is no difference.
Question:
Why is there one less sentence in the conclusion?
Answer:
Since it is said that the acceptance is precisely the perfections, one should know that the perfections are precisely the acceptance, and therefore the second sentence is not necessary.
There are also two meanings in the conclusion:
First, it concludes that wisdom is no different from the perfections, and second, it concludes that embracing the true Dharma is no different from the perfections.
Question:

Embracing is the wisdom that embraces, and the true Dharma is the practice of the six perfections. Since wisdom and practice are not two, how can the essence of a single wisdom encompass all practices?
Answer:

Just as a single correct contemplation, in terms of the meaning of stopping evil, is called morality, in terms of the meaning of realizing stillness, it is called concentration, in terms of the meaning of being able to illuminate, it is called wisdom, and in terms of the meaning of reaching the end, it is the perfections. Therefore, a single wisdom encompasses all practices.
Question:

If the six perfections are no different from correct contemplation, this is the non-difference of understanding and practice. Can it also be said that the true Dharma of reality is no different from the six perfections?
Answer:
Above, it was clarified that wisdom is no different from principle. In terms of wisdom and principle, it is practice.
Since wisdom is no different from principle, it is the same as practice being no different from principle.
Question:
How are they no different?
Answer:
The bodhisattva practices the six perfections with a mind of true reality, therefore the six perfections are the true reality.
Now, let us explain it in terms of giving. Although it is devoid of the four, the three things are still apparent.
This true reality is giving. Although the three things are still apparent, it is always devoid of the four. Therefore, giving is the true reality.
Since the perfection of giving is like this, the other practices are the same.
Question:

Above, it was explained that the four vehicles of cause and effect arise from the true reality. The bodhisattva uses the four vehicles of cause and effect to benefit others. How is this different from the explanation of embracing the true Dharma now?
Answer:
Above, it explained benefiting others with the Dharma of the four vehicles. Now, it explains benefiting beings with the practice of the six perfections.
If that is so, above it is the four vehicles, and benefiting beings with the six perfections is the One Vehicle.
The previous is benefiting beings by giving rise to [the four vehicles], and now it is benefiting others by gathering [the six perfections].

Moreover, above it clarified the arising of practice from principle, and now it clarifies the completion of practice. Therefore, using practice to benefit beings, above it clarified the root, and now it distinguishes the branches.
Why is it so? Below this, above it is the first clarification of embracing and accepting, and now it is the second clarification of the true Dharma.
Also, above it is the indication, and now it is the explanation.
Why is it so? This is a question.
The meaning of the question is:
Why is embracing and accepting the true Dharma precisely the six perfections?
Embracing and accepting the true Dharma and below this is the answer.
The meaning of the answer is:
The six pÄramitÄs are precisely the true Dharma.
Bodhisattvas embrace and accept the true Dharma of the six pÄramitÄs and transform it in people, therefore, embracing and accepting the true Dharma is no different from the pÄramitÄs.
Herein, the clarification of the six pÄramitÄs is precisely the six stages, and each of the six pÄramitÄs has three phrases:
First, indicating the conditions, second, clarifying the bodhisattva's practice of giving, third, concluding the practice as being a pÄramitÄ.
The first phrase should be accomplished through giving clarifies the receptive capacities of those to be converted.
Question:
What kind of people are these?
Answer:
Some say these are stingy and greedy beings, who should be taught to practice giving, thus called accomplishment.
I now say the textual meaning is not so.

The sutra says should be accomplished through giving, which clarifies that the receptive capacities of others should see the bodhisattva practicing giving to attain accomplishment, and the bodhisattva will then practice giving for them.
How is it related to teaching others to practice giving?
All six perfections have this text, and it must be determined beforehand.
Question:
What kind of people are these?
Answer:
These people are not fixed.
There are stingy and greedy beings who are unwilling to give, and the bodhisattva practices giving in front of them, causing them to learn it.

Second, there are poor sentient beings. The bodhisattva gives them wealth and property, causing them to rejoice and become the bodhisattva's retinue. He then transforms them to enter the Way, thus it is said to accomplish them through giving.
There are sentient beings who should see the bodhisattva practicing giving in order to attain enlightenment. Therefore, the bodhisattva practices giving for their sake.
Through accomplishing giving - the second is clarifying the bodhisattva's practice of giving.
The text is divided into two parts:
First, it presents two chapter headings; second, it explains the two chapter headings.
Through accomplishing giving - it presents the two chapter headings.
The single word giving refers to the chapter heading of the bodhisattva practicing giving.
Accomplishing refers to the chapter heading of benefiting beings.
Up to giving away one's body and limbs - it explains the two chapter headings.
It immediately explains the chapter heading of practicing giving.
Giving is internal and external. Giving away the body is internal, giving away the rest is external.
From the outside to the inside, it is said to be even to the point of giving up one's body and limbs.
Even to the point of is a phrase expressing thoroughness.
Protecting their minds and below explains the second accomplished chapter.
Protecting their minds means skillfully conforming with the capacities and conditions, which is called protecting their minds.
Although bodhisattvas may internally and externally give up everything, this accords with principle but may not necessarily suit the capacities.
Now, wanting to clarify what suits the capacities, it says protecting their minds.
And accomplishing it and below, using the practice of giving in accordance with the capacities and conditions, the other person then benefits, thus it says and accomplishing it.
The sentient beings they accomplish and establish the true Dharma explains the meaning of accomplishment above.

Bodhisattvas, with the mind of embracing the true Dharma, practice giving for the sake of beings, thus causing sentient beings to awaken to the Way and enter into the midst of embracing the true Dharma.

Therefore, upholding the true Dharma attains the practice of giving, and also attains the upholding of all sentient beings. Therefore, the meaning of upholding the true Dharma is vast, so it was said before that upholding the true Dharma is the pÄramitÄs.
Since giving is like this, the other five are also the same.
There are two aspects to upholding the true Dharma:
First, upholding practice, which means upholding the true Dharma, upholding the true Dharma, and upholding the myriad practices such as the six pÄramitÄs;
Second, upholding conditions, which means that when bodhisattvas practice the six pÄramitÄs, they enable all sentient beings to attain enlightenment and enter the true Dharma.
Therefore, the meaning of upholding the true Dharma is vast.
This is called the perfection of giving is the third, concluding the accomplishment of the practice of giving.
Protecting the six sense faculties is the second, the perfection of morality.
It also has three parts:
First, identifying the conditions; second, explaining the bodhisattva's practice of morality; third, concluding the accomplishment of the practice and calling it the perfection.
Should accomplish through morality identifies the conditions.
Question:
What are these conditions?
Answer:
There are also many kinds.
There are conditions for breaking precepts that cause one to repent and uphold the precepts;
there are those who have not yet received precepts, causing them to receive precepts;
there are those who see upholding the precepts and give rise to a mind of reverence, and there are those who see upholding the precepts and attain enlightenment.
Question:
Why are many conditions given for each stage?
Answer:
If it were like the MahÄprajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ SÅ«tra, each stage would have four phrases:

First, practicing the six pÄramitÄs oneself; second, teaching others to practice; third, praising the practice; fourth, extolling the practitioner. Then each of the six pÄramitÄs would correspond to six conditions.
In this text, the medicine is specific and the illness is general, clarifying the six practices, so it is specific medicine;
the conditions it addresses are not specifically indicated, knowing the illness is general.
By guarding the six sense faculties - second, clarifying the bodhisattva upholding the precepts.
The text is divided into two parts:
First, it clarifies the bodhisattva's own upholding of precepts.
Second, it clarifies how the bodhisattva's upholding of precepts benefits others.

Guarding the six sense faculties means that the six sense faculties are like doors that can lead to the six sense objects, which are evil thieves that harm and destroy good conduct. Therefore, one must guard against them.
The method of guarding is only mindfulness and wisdom. The mindful mind guards the sense objects, and wisdom skillfully distinguishes and knows their benefits and harm.

Purifying the activities of body, speech, and mind means that the bodhisattva's upholding of precepts has a beginning and an end. Guarding the six sense faculties is the beginning, and the accomplishment of pure conduct of body, speech, and mind is the end.
Within the accomplishment, purifying body, speech, and mind is the correct precept that is free from offenses against morality.
Up to the correct four deportments refers to being free from offenses against the precepts.
Up to is still a word expressing thoroughness.

Offenses against morality are easy to avoid, while offenses against the precepts are difficult to guard against. From easy to difficult, it is also from heavy to light, so it says up to the correct four deportments.
Protecting their minds means that the first part clarifies the bodhisattva upholding precepts, and now the second part clarifies causing others to practice precepts, fully as explained above.
This is called - the third part concludes the name of the practice of complete precepts as pÄramitÄ.
In the practice of patience, there are also three parts:
First, it states one should accomplish patience through - indicating the conditions for what is to be endured.
If those sentient beings - the second part clarifies the bodhisattva practicing patience, which is also twofold:
First, it clarifies practicing patience; second, it is for accomplishing sentient beings.

Scolded, reviled, humiliated, and slandered are verbal humiliations. Discussing face-to-face is called scolding, speaking behind one's back is called humiliation, and completely disregarding is called slander.
Fear is a physical humiliation, and events such as beating, binding, cutting, and imprisoning are called fear.
Moreover, fear also extends to the mouth, because speaking of various evil events frightens others.
With a mind of non-anger - this clarifies patience.
Because one attains the wholesome roots of non-anger, it is called non-anger.
A mind of benefit - not only being without anger, when bodhisattvas see being struck or scolded, they give rise to a mind of benefit towards the other person.
When arhats are struck or scolded, their minds are also not angry, but they are unable to immediately give rise to a compassionate mind and benefit others;
bodhisattvas are able to do so.
The power of supreme patience - patience is the supreme path.
As it is said in the sÅ«tras, The virtue of patience cannot be reached by upholding precepts or ascetic practices, thus it is called supreme.
Moreover, the MahÄprajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ-Å›Ästra says, When practicing the patience of sentient beings, one attains immeasurable merit.
When practicing the patience of dharmas, one attains immeasurable wisdom.
Virtue encompasses blessings and wisdom, thus it is called supreme.
Up to not changing one's facial expression - up to is still a word for reaching the end.
When bodhisattvas practice patience, they do not give rise to anger or harbor grudges, nor do they retaliate. This is avoiding grave faults.
Now, it is explained that they are without change, far removed from minor faults.
Protecting and below is the second, the same as before.
This is called and below is the third, concluding the perfection of patience.
The perfection of vigor also has three parts, easy to understand.
Bodhisattvas' vigorous effort is for the sake of liberating sentient beings. Therefore, it is said, Toward those sentient beings, they do not give rise to a lazy mind.
This clarifies avoiding faults, as the sÅ«tras say, Laziness is an obstruction for vigorous effort, and indolence is a defilement of vigorous effort.
Obstructions are grave, while defilements are light. Now, it is explained to be free from the light [defilements].
How could there be grave [obstructions] when there is not even the light [defilements]?
Giving rise to a great desirous mind - above it clarified avoiding faults, now it distinguishes cultivating virtues.
Having the intention to cultivate all wholesome dharmas is called a great desirous mind.
Moreover, having the intention to save all sentient beings is called the mind of great desire.
The mind of desire is the skillful means of vigor, so it arises first.
The foremost vigor is the essence of vigor.
The foremost vigor is the vigor of the mind.
Up to and below refers to physical vigor, always able to diligently practice while walking, standing, sitting, or lying down.
It is called whether in the four deportments, the mind is easy and the body is difficult.
Because the body arises from the mind, it is said to be up to.
The perfection of meditation is also threefold.
With a mind that is not confused towards those sentient beings, a mind that does not turn outward means the mind does not dwell on a single object, which is called a confused mind.
The mind takes external objects as its object, which is called a mind that turns outward.
This is an obstacle to concentration. Because bodhisattvas attain concentration, they stay far away from it.
Some people say:ğŸ”½Not confused means being free from natural confusion.
Not turning outward means being free from circumstantial confusion.
The Buddha-Nature Treatise says, Nature-disturbance is disturbance within the five consciousnesses, and event-disturbance is disturbance within the mental consciousness.
Also, the VimalakÄ«rti-nirdeÅ›a SÅ«tra says, The mind does not dwell internally or externally, this is the meditative absorption of the bodhisattva.
First, right mindfulness - above it clarifies what is to be abandoned, now it clarifies what is to be attained.
The emptiness of beings and the emptiness of dharmas, always using the principle of emptiness to comfort oneself, therefore it is called right mindfulness.
Question:
The emptiness of beings and the emptiness of dharmas, this is right wisdom, why is it said to be right concentration?
Answer:
It is a single contemplation of emptiness, spoken of in two meanings. Exhaustive illumination is called wisdom, ultimate stillness is called concentration.
Therefore the Satyasiddhi ÅšÄstra says, At that time, the two kinds are called wisdom when they are known as they really are, and they are called samÄdhi when the mind is concentrated.
Also, mindfulness is the cause of dhyÄna, able to give rise to a concentrated mind, like the dhyÄna factors and the four bases of supernatural power.
It does not speak of the first right concentration, but mentions its cause, in contrast to the following not forgetting, to show the power of guarding the object.
Even after a long time, what was done refers to bodily actions.
What was said for a long time refers to verbal actions.
Never forgotten clarifies that the concentrated mind always remembers, and the bodily and verbal actions done for a long time are not forgotten.
Question:
Why does this thought come about?
Answer:
Because the bodhisattva, due to concentration, gives rise to the supernormal knowledge of past lives, he remembers events done for a long time.
Moreover, due to concentration, he attains the three wheels:
The first right mindfulness refers to attaining the wheel of knowing others' minds due to concentration;
What was done for a long time is the wheel of spiritual powers;
What was said for a long time is the wheel of teaching the Dharma, and none of it is forgotten.

When the mind is agitated, the emotions are obscured; when the spirit is still, the thoughts are clear. Therefore, seeing events from a distant eon is like seeing them in front of one's eyes. Therefore, it is said that they are not forgotten.
Wisdom is also threefold:
Those sentient beings ask about all meanings means they ask about all meanings of the five sciences and so forth, and also ask about all meanings of the five dharma repositories.
The five dharma repositories are the three times for three, the unconditioned for four, and the ineffable for five.

Expounding with a fearless mind means that fear arises from delusion, and peace arises from understanding. Since one is already well-versed, one can respond to difficulties and can certainly resolve them, thus it says expounding with a fearless mind.

All discourses refers to worldly discourses, worldly discourses, Veda discourses, VyÄkaraá¹‡a discourses, VaiÅ›eá¹£ika discourses.ğŸ”½These are also the five sciences, which are created by wise people.
Moreover, those who study these discourses can also give rise to people's wisdom, thus they are called the five sciences.

As for the five treatises, they are the treatise on inner [doctrine], the treatise on logic, the treatise on language, the treatise on medicine, and the treatise on crafts. Therefore, they are called the five.
These five all require the host and guest to measure [the truth], therefore they are called treatises.
But the first four kinds, because the texts are mostly used as a basis, are called treatises;
The fifth gate, following the events, is practiced, and should be called crafts.
Therefore, the text says all treatises and all crafts.
These five are the places where bright wisdom is born, therefore they are called bright places.

The meaning is common to both the true and the worldly, therefore the BodhisattvabhÅ«mi-sÅ«tra says in the five bright places, all hearing, thinking, practicing, and realizing are fulfilled, which means it is known to be common to the two truths, as explained in detail in the BodhisattvabhÅ«mi-Å›Ästra.
Up to various crafts and activities, up to is still a word for reaching the end, starting from the first inner treatise, up to the fifth various crafts and activities.
Therefore, World-Honored One, there is no other pÄramitÄ than the acceptance of the true Dharma. The acceptance of the true Dharma is no different from the pÄramitÄs in three ways:
First, it generally states that there is no difference;
Second, from Why is it so? below, it specifically explains the non-difference in terms of the six pÄramitÄs;
Now, the third is the general conclusion that there is no difference.
Question:
In other places, the six pÄramitÄs are all considered one's own practice. Why is it said here to be for transforming others?
Answer:
The objects to which they correspond are different.
In other places, they are compared to the four means of conversion, so they are one's own practice;
Now, they are compared to the internal virtues of acceptance, and practicing the six pÄramitÄs for the sake of beings is called transforming others.
Question:
Giving is giving to others, and the four means of conversion convert others. Why are the six pÄramitÄs one's own practice, and the four means of conversion are for transforming others?
Answer:
In the six pÄramitÄs, it only says giving, so it is one's own practice;
In the means of conversion, it says giving converts, and conversion is precisely transforming others, so it is for transforming others.
Question:
Why are the six pÄramitÄs taken as the practice of transforming others here?
Answer:
To explain the above, which is the Dharma of Immeasurable Meanings.
The Dharma of Immeasurable Meanings is still another name for vastness.
If one practices the six pÄramitÄs oneself, then the practice is not vast;
But by practicing the six for the sake of others, the six pÄramitÄs are vast.
Moreover, the six pÄramitÄs have three kinds of vastness:
First, there is no evil that is not stopped; second, there is no practice that is not cultivated; third, there is no person that is not liberated, and they are also called vast.
World-Honored One, I now rely on the Buddha's majestic spiritual power - the third is next explaining the above chapter on attaining all the Buddha's teachings.

The reason it is known that it explains the chapter on attaining all the Buddha's teachings is that below it clarifies abandoning the three unwholesome things and attaining the three wholesome things.
The three wholesome things are precisely the Buddha's teachings on the fruition ground, so it is known that this explains the above chapter on the fruition virtues.

Moreover, it connects with the text on the six perfections. Above it clarifies practicing the six perfections, which is benefiting sentient beings below. Now practicing the six perfections is seeking Buddhahood above, so with the cause of the six perfections one attains the fruit of the three firmnesses.
But the text is based on the cause of giving and attaining the fruit of giving.
The other practices are of the same kind, so this text comes.
Moreover, above it clarifies the six perfections, which is precisely transforming others. Now clarifying abandoning the three and attaining the three is precisely one's own practice.

Moreover, above it clarifies the six perfections, which is precisely the vast practice. Now clarifying abandoning the three and being equal to the final limit is precisely the long duration, both fully possessing the various meanings.
In the text, there are also three parts:
First, requesting to speak; second, permission to speak; third, proper speaking.

The reason for calling it relying on power again here is that above it clarifies the easy explanation of the causal practices, and now it clarifies the difficult explanation of the fruition virtues, thus it relies on the Buddha's power again.
Speaking of the great meaning again means that above it clarifies the great principle and great practice, and now it further speaks of the great fruition.

Moreover, above it has already explained the causes and benefits of the six perfections. Now it explains abandoning the three and attaining the three of the higher seeking, therefore it is called the great meaning.
It is acceptable to explain.
ÅšrÄ«mÄlÄ said to the Buddha - the third is the correct explanation.
The text is divided into two parts:
The first clarifies abandoning the three and attaining the three, the second praises.
The first part is also divided into two:
The first clarifies the acceptance, the second explains the true Dharma.
Question:
How is the acceptance now different from the above?
Answer:
Above it clarifies the acceptance of principle, which is the non-difference of wisdom and principle;
Next it clarifies the acceptance of practice, which is the non-difference of wisdom and practice.
Now it clarifies the acceptance of fruition. The so-called fruition refers to the constant body, life, and wealth of the Buddha ground.
It clarifies that the person accepts this fruition Dharma, therefore the person and the fruition Dharma are non-dual.
The reason for this is that the person who realizes the constant body, life, and wealth is of the same essence as the constant body and life, therefore the person and Dharma are non-dual.

Moreover, this clarifies the mind of non-attainment. Abandoning the three is precisely the practice of giving of one who abides in the true Dharma, which is non-dual with this practice of giving that abides in the true Dharma.
Question:
Above, the six pÄramitÄs were already clarified as non-dual. Why is the practice of giving clarified as non-dual again?
Answer:
Although the practice was already clarified as extensive above, now the duration is clarified as long.
There should be four meanings in the transition.
If one has not yet attained the contemplation of the non-duality of person and dharmas, then person and dharmas are dual;
If one attains the contemplation of non-duality, then it clarifies that person and dharmas are non-dual.
Moreover, in order to destroy the duality of person and dharmas, it clarifies the non-duality of person and dharmas.
The deluded think that person can embrace the true Dharma, and the true Dharma is embraced by person, thus giving rise to two views;
In order to destroy the two, it clarifies non-duality, as fully explained above.
Moreover, it fully possesses the two meanings of non-duality and non-duality while being dual.
Dharmas form a person, and a person can master the Dharma. Dual yet non-dual, it is called a person who unifies and governs the Dharma, and it is called the Dharma that can be practiced by a person.

Moreover, the Dharma of people can give rise to the causes and effects of the four vehicles, and the people in the Dharma can also give rise to the causes and effects of the four vehicles. Since their functions are the same, people and Dharma are not two.
Therefore, in the first four parables, the first two clarify the Dharma giving rise to [results], and the latter two clarify people giving rise to [results]. This is the matter.
The first text has three sentences:
The first is a double citation of people and Dharma.ğŸ”½There is no difference between those who accept the true Dharma clarifies that people are not different from the Dharma.
There is no difference between those who accept the true Dharma distinguishes that the Dharma is not different from people.
Good men and good women who accept the true Dharma concludes that people are the Dharma.
Why is it so? above it clarified acceptance, now the second is clarifying the true Dharma, the true Dharma is precisely the eternal body, life, and wealth.
Why is it so? is the question.
This question has two meanings:
The first is asking about the true Dharma that is accepted, the second is asking why people and Dharma are not two.
If one embraces the true Dharma and below is the correct answer to the two questions.
The general meaning clarifies that this person, having abandoned the three parts, obtains the constant body, life, and wealth within embracing.
The body and life are precisely the true Dharma, thus answering the first question.
The constant body, life, and wealth are what make up a person, thus the person is not different from the Dharma, answering the second question.
There are three parts in the text:
First, generally clarifying that this person, in order to embrace the true Dharma, therefore abandons the three parts;
Second, listing the three names;
Third, extensively explaining.

In the first part, If one embraces the true Dharma, men and women, in order to embrace the true Dharma, therefore abandon the three parts, this clarifies that the bodhisattva who embraces, in order to attain the constant body, life, and wealth of the Buddha fruit, therefore abandons the three impermanent parts.
This clarifies the intention of abandonment.
Question:
One should simply say that in order to attain the constant body, life, and wealth, one abandons the three parts. Why is it said that in order to embrace the true Dharma, one abandons the three parts?
Answer:
It is to show that the meaning of embracing the true Dharma is vast.
Since it clarifies that it is for embracing the true Dharma, one should know that embracing the true Dharma is precisely the constant body, life, and wealth.

If it is said that it is for the sake of the constant body, life, and wealth to abandon the three parts, then one may think that embracing the true Dharma does not include the constant body, life, and wealth.
For this reason, it is said to be for embracing the true Dharma.
What are the three? Below this is the second listing of the three names.
Question:
How is abandoning the body, life, and wealth different?
Answer:
If one abandons the body to become a slave, then abandoning life is not allowed.
Moreover, abandoning the head, eyes, and limbs to give to others is abandoning the body, but taking death for others is abandoning life.
Another explanation:
Abandoning the body is precisely abandoning life, but the original intention is different, so it forms two distinctions.
For example, throwing oneself to save a tiger, although life is not preserved, using the flesh to give to them, the intention is in giving the body.
They cannot bear my presence and must get me to die, only then can their matter be accomplished.
The bodhisattva, for this reason, gives up his life. Although the body does not remain, this is only giving up life.
Apart from one's own life, the country, city, wife, and children are all given to others, which is giving away wealth.
Emperor Wu of the Liang Dynasty separately explained this as a small section of meaning.
Good sons and below is the third extensive explanation, which forms three distinctions.
Men and women are those who can give up.
Giving up the body clarifies giving up.
The end of birth and death is equal - people in the north have two explanations:
One says that birth and death are the past, and nirvana is the future. As for equal, birth and death and nirvana are not the same in terms of events, but are equal in principle.
It is necessary to attain this equality in order to have giving up and attaining.
Equality refers to the contemplation of emptiness and equality, cutting off nirvana above and obliterating birth and death below.
By attaining these contemplations, one can transcend old age, sickness, and death, and obtain eternal body, life, and wealth.

This contemplation of emptiness and equality is for the sake of abandoning gain. This is called abandoning because it is the realization of the true characteristic of separation, not because giving one's body to others is called abandoning.
Some people say:
The end of birth and death is not taking birth and death as the beginning and nirvana as the end, but rather distinguishing the beginning and end within birth and death itself.
If one is an ordinary person bound by all fetters, this is the beginning of birth and death;
Having one type of affliction remaining in the vajra-like samÄdhi is the end of birth and death, so the vajra-like samÄdhi is called the end of birth and death.
As for equality, it refers to the Buddha's fruition of the wisdom of the knower of all aspects.

This is because the vajra-like [samÄdhi] severs [afflictions] and realizes the wisdom of the knower of all aspects. This is based on the point of ultimate completion to speak, so it mentions the equality of the end.
The people of the south also have two explanations, but they have differences and similarities.
One says:
Taking the vajra-like [concentration] as the end of birth, referring to the end of birth and death at this time.
It clarifies that the matter of giving up the body begins from the initial arousal of the mind and ends here as the ultimate. From here on, there is no more impermanent body to give up.
Another explanation:
Taking nirvana as the end, birth and death end at this time, thus it is said the end of birth and death and so on.
In the *MahÄvibhÄá¹£Ä, both explanations are given, but there they mention the lesser nirvana, while here it is the great nirvana that is different.
The meaning of Master Fu:
Embracing the true Dharma, with enlightenment as the goal, giving up body, life, and wealth with the limit of the end of time.
Now it is necessary to measure it.
People in the north take emptiness and equality as giving up, but this is not so.

In discussing the giving of emptiness and equality, from the first ground one can attain the contemplation of equality and immediately be able to practice giving equally. How can it be said that only at the end of time does one discern the giving of emptiness and equality?
If nirvana is taken as the final limit, this is the ultimate point of abandoning the impermanent body. Beyond this, there is no more impermanent body to abandon. This statement is reasonable.
If vajra is taken as the final limit, vajra is still a later part of samsara, and there is still an impermanent body to abandon.
If nirvana is taken as the final limit, one attains the eternal body and there is no more impermanent body to give.
One only attains the eternal and abandons the impermanent, and from this perspective, it can also be said that there is an impermanent body to abandon.
Now, examining the meaning of the sutra, going from cause to effect is as explained above.
But now it is said to be equal to the final limit. Samsara itself has three limits:
The first is the prior limit, which refers to the past;
The second is the middle limit, which refers to the present;
The third is the final limit, which refers to the future.
Since the limits are endless, the abandonment of the body equal to the final limit is also endless.
Like the ten meanings of inexhaustibility in the Sutra on the Ten Grounds, it does not take exhaustion as equality.
Question:
If the end of the future is endless and the abandonment of the body is also endless, how can one attain the fruit of permanence?
Answer:
The bodhisattva establishes an endless mind, and when the practice is fulfilled, one naturally attains permanence.
Free from old age, sickness, and death - above it clarifies the cause of practice, now it distinguishes the attainment of the fruit.
Abandoning the impermanent body and practicing giving, one generally attains two fruits:
First, the fruit of what is abandoned, and second, the fruit of what is attained.
Being free from old age, sickness, and death is called the fruit of what is abandoned.
Old age and sickness are only in the stage of conditioned arising, while the meaning of death is common to both transformation and change.
Moreover, transformation and change also have the old age of moment-to-moment and the sickness of impermanence.
Attaining the indestructible permanence and below is the second clarification of the fruit of attainment.
There are three parts in the text:
First, the permanence attained, second, the profundity attained, and third, the essence attained.
The essence is permanent, so it is called the Dharma body.
There are also no dharmas that are not Dharma, and this wondrous Dharma is fulfilled, which is the meaning of the Dharma body.
Since one gives up one's body for the sake of others, one attains the reward of the Dharma body.
This is discussed based on similar causes.
It is called permanent because it cannot be destroyed, referring to being free from the segmented [body].
It is without change, free from change.
Moreover, being without change explains the permanence above.
Inconceivable merits - the second clarifies what is deeply attained.
Since the path surpasses the three vehicles and ten grounds, no one can conceive of it.
The Dharma body of the TathÄgata - the third clarifies the essence of what is attained.
Since the body is formed by meritorious dharmas, it is called the body of merits.
Giving up one's life - this introduces the giving of one's life.
The end of birth and death - this clarifies the length of time of giving.
Ultimately free from death - above it distinguishes the causes of practice, now it clarifies the attainment of the fruit.
There are two parts:
First, what is to be abandoned, second, what is to be attained.
Free from death refers to what is to be abandoned.
Abandoning life is being taken by others, so being free from death is the result.
Impermanent life must inevitably have death, but now it is explained that there is no death, so it is said to be free from death.
Attaining boundless permanence below clarifies what is attained.
It is also threefold:
First, the permanence that is attained; second, the profundity that is attained; third, the essence that is attained.
Boundless means that the life of birth and death has its limits, which is called bound.
The permanent life is different from that, so it is said to be boundless.
Because it is boundless, it is therefore permanently abiding.
Inconceivable merit clarifies the profundity that is attained. All sentient beings are unable to conceive of the lifespan of the TathÄgata and know its limits, so it is called inconceivable.
This permanent life is attained through cultivating merit, so it is called merit.
Penetrating and below is the third, the essence that is attained.
Merit generally clarifies its essence.
Penetrating all profound Buddhist teachings specifically brings out the essence of life, which is precisely using wisdom as life.

The reason why wisdom is emphasized is because wisdom is the leader of practice and can uphold various virtues, just as life can sustain the rewards of form and mind. Therefore, wisdom is called life.
Penetrating all refers to vast wisdom.
Profound Buddhist teachings refers to profound wisdom.
Using this vast and profound wisdom as life is called the life of wisdom.
As the sutra says, The life of Subhuti and The life of Shariputra.
Now, penetrating all profound Buddhist teachings brings out the realm illuminated by the life of wisdom.
Giving away wealth refers to what is given away.
The end of birth and death is no different from the above explanation.
Not shared and below clarifies the attainment of fruition.
Only clarifying what is attained also includes what is abandoned.
There are two in this:
First, obtaining one's own karmic wealth, second, obtaining the wealth of others' offerings.
In one's own karmic wealth, there are also three:
First, what is obtained is constant, second, what is obtained is profound, third, what is obtained is the essence.
As for obtaining the uncommon, worldly wealth is shared by the five families.
Now, by abandoning worldly wealth, one obtains uncommon wealth.
Worldly wealth may be exhausted or diminished, but constant wealth is inexhaustible and undiminished.
Ultimately constant distinguishes it from impermanent wealth, and now it manifests as constant wealth.
Question:
What is constant wealth?
Answer:
The Fahua Lun explains that my pure land is not destroyed, yet the masses see it burned to the ground. Tianpin says:
The pure land of the reward Buddha Tathagata is subsumed within the ultimate truth and cannot be burned.
That treatise clarifies that the reward Buddha is eternal, and the land of the reward Buddha is also eternal, so it is eternal wealth.
Some people say:
Constant wealth refers to the ten powers, which are the immeasurable Buddha-dharmas, and are therefore called wealth.
As the VimalakÄ«rti-nirdeÅ›a-sÅ«tra says, Rich in the seven treasures, thus using the many virtues as wealth.
Inconceivable and below is the second revealing the profundity of what is attained.
Endowed with merit and below is the third revealing the essence of what is attained, which is using merit as wealth.
Moreover, above, ultimately abiding establishes the inexhaustibility;
Endowed with merit establishes the non-decrease above.
In general discussion, worldly wealth has five aspects:
1. Shared by the five families, 2. Diminishing, 3. Exhaustible, 4. Impermanent, 5. Not wonderful;
The Dharma wealth is the opposite of this.
Receiving the unsurpassed offerings of all sentient beings - there are two kinds of wealth:
1. Wealth of one's own retribution, 2. Wealth offered by others.
The pure land realm that one attracts is wealth of retribution, while the offerings of devas and humans are wealth offered by others.
The above clarifies one's own offerings, now the offerings of others are discussed.

In terms of the traces of response, once the response is manifested, it can attract sentient beings' excellent offerings of the four requisites, and can also attract the excellent offerings of the four requisites from the sages of the three vehicles.
The World-Honored One thus abandons the three parts and below, above the first clarifies the non-duality of person and Dharma, practicing causes and attaining fruits, now the second praises.
There are two sentences in total:
The first restates the person being praised;
Always and below clearly show the praise.
There are two in the praise:
The first is being recorded by the Buddha above, and the second is being looked up to by sentient beings below.
Moreover, above it enters the Buddha's realm, so it is recorded by the Buddha;
Below it surpasses the multitude, so it is looked up to by the masses.
Question:
Why is it said to be recorded by the Buddha?
Answer:
Abandoning body and wealth, this is a great matter.
People may not necessarily attain the fruit, so it is clarified that practicing causes will definitely have fruits to be attained, thus the Buddha records it.
Moreover, prediction means certainty, that person will definitely attain the three fruits.
Moreover, prediction means distinction, that person will definitely become a Buddha without practicing the eightfold path.

As for being looked up to by sentient beings, sentient beings cannot abandon the three, but that person can abandon them. Sentient beings are weary of impermanence and delight in permanence, but that person attains permanence, therefore being looked up to by others.
Moreover, above it promotes the Buddha's teachings, therefore being predicted by the Buddha;
now it accomplishes sentient beings, therefore being looked up to by sentient beings.
World-Honored One, moreover, good men... and below, from above, it has already explained the three chapters, namely principle, practice, and fruition.
Based on principle, practice is accomplished, based on practice, fruition is attained, this is one's own practice.
Once one's own practice is accomplished, then it clarifies benefiting others.
Benefiting others refers to the eighty-four thousand Dharma gates, which is the ultimate in benefiting others.
Therefore, above there are four headings, and here there are four explanations.
Question:
Now the text clarifies the protection of the Dharma, why do you say it explains the above 84,000 teachings?
Answer:
The protector of the Dharma correctly clarifies the protection of the teachings.
Therefore, now clarifying the protection of the Dharma is explaining the above teachings.
Abandoning the false teachings and revealing the correct teachings is called protecting the Dharma.
There is also this text coming, explaining the three intentions of abandonment.
The reason for abandoning the three is to protect the Dharma.
As the third vow above says, For the sake of protecting the true Dharma, I will give up my body, life, and wealth.
The Buddha-nature Treatise clarifies ten reasons for permanence, the first principle says, Giving up body, life, and wealth is to embrace the true Dharma.
Since the true Dharma is endless, using an endless cause to elicit an endless result, the result is the three bodies, therefore it is permanent.
Moreover, it completes the above attainment of the three, as the Nirvana Sutra says, The cause and condition of protecting the Dharma is to attain the vajra body.
Moreover, the bodhisattva abandons the three for two things:
First, for the sake of benefiting sentient beings below, second, for the sake of protecting the great Dharma above.

Previously, it was explained for the sake of benefiting the four kinds of birth, therefore abandoning the three. Now, for the sake of protecting the Three Jewels above, therefore abandoning the three.
Question:
In the previous three, all the acceptance and protection are explained. Why is acceptance and protection not explained in the Dharma protection?
Answer:
The principle, practice, and fruition are the meaning of realization, therefore acceptance and protection are explained;
In the Dharma protection, the teaching is explained, therefore acceptance and protection is not explained.
Also, for the sake of brevity, and by analogy with the previous, it can be known.
In the text, there are four parts:
First, it raises the person who protects the Dharma;
Second, When the Dharma is about to perish, it distinguishes the time of protecting the Dharma;
Third, Not flattery, it reveals the practice of protection;
Fourth, Entering the Dharma faction, the benefits of protection are accomplished.
Good men and good women refers to those who protect the Dharma.
When the Dharma is about to perish refers to the time of protecting the Dharma.
Bhikshus and below refer to those who destroy the Dharma.
The Sanskrit word bhiká¹£u is translated in this land in five ways:
First, it is called frightening demons, because when one first leaves home, it frightens demons. This meaning is based on the beginning.
Second, it is called begging for alms, because after leaving home, one does not accumulate anything, but seeks to sustain oneself through begging.
Third, it is called pure livelihood, because one seeks through the Dharma, leaving behind wrong livelihood.
These two are based on the next.
Fourth, it is called purely upholding precepts, because after leaving home, one cultivates and upholds the precepts of purity.
Fifth, it is called destroying evil, because by upholding the precepts, one leaves behind the evil of violating the precepts.
These two are based on the end.
Ni means woman.
UpÄsaka is translated as good-abiding man.
Embracing goodness and abiding by oneself, it is called good-abiding man.
It is also called closely abiding, because by embracing goodness and abiding by oneself, one is close to the Buddha's abode.
Yi means woman.
If these four people are able to practice according to the teachings, they are Dharma protectors.
Therefore, the Renwang Jing says: Just as a lion is not eaten by other beasts, but is eaten by the worms in its own body.
The Buddha's teachings are also like this. Heavenly demons and non-Buddhist paths cannot destroy my teachings. It is still my four types of disciples who can destroy my teachings.
Factions and disputes are the characteristics of the decline of the Dharma.
Factions means the mind is corrupted.
Disputes means the mouth is corrupted.
Destruction and dispersal refers to the corruption of the body.
Moreover, compiling heretical precepts and emotionally supporting each other is called factions.
Disputing right and wrong is called disputes.
Dividing into different groups is called destruction.
Each practicing separately is called dispersal.
Moreover, it is also destroying the harmonious assembly, so it is called dispersal.
Without flattery and below clarifies the protection of the Dharma.
There are six sentences in total:
The first three are different from evil, and the last three are the same as the correct.
Not deceitful means the body is not crooked.
Following evil companions is called deceitfulness.
Not deceptive means the mouth is not crooked.
Proclaiming false teachings with the mouth is called deception.
Not illusory means the mind is not crooked.
Confused mind and false teachings are called illusory.
Moreover, not deceitful means being free from the defilement of deceitfulness, not pretending to be good externally.
Not deceptive means being free from the defilement of deception, not concealing internal evil.
The four-fascicle *Abhidharma says crookedness arises from deceitfulness and pretense, so now they are combined into not deceitful.

The *Satyasiddhi ÅšÄstra says the mind of deceitfulness is accomplished, therefore it is called deception, so after not deceitful, it clarifies not deceptive.ğŸ”½Not illusory means if one pretends to be good externally and conceals internal evil, it is called illusory.
Because one does not pretend to be good externally or conceal internal evil, it is called not illusory.
Lin Gong said:
Verbal karma is deception, mental karma is flattery, and physical karma is pretense.
Moreover, a Dharma teacher, towards those who are superior, will flatter them to their face, and towards those who are inferior, will deceive them, with an insincere mind, which is called pretense.
Like when Brahma Heaven King was teaching the Dharma to the Brahma sons, the bhiká¹£u Black Teeth used his spiritual powers to go there and asked:
From what samÄdhi does this body arise?
In what samÄdhi does it cease?
He was unable to answer, but only said:
I am the Great Brahma King.
I am the Great Brahma King.
When he had finished teaching the Dharma, he took Black Teeth's hand and said:
You should not ask me in the assembly.
This is flattering Black Teeth and deceiving the lesser Brahmas, with an insincere mind in both places.
Moreover, the two inverted views of ordinary beings are called flattery, and the non-finality of the two vehicles is called deception.
ÅšÄriputra said:
Alas, I deeply reproach myself.
How could I deceive?
The bodhisattva with a mind of emptiness and confusion is called a false one.
Now the bodhisattva who protects the Dharma has none of these two minds.
Below, the same as the correct, loving and delighting in the true Dharma, is the correct mind.
Upholding the true Dharma, is the correct speech.
Good words seeking the Dharma are called upholding.
Moreover, loving and delighting is entering the correct practice.
Moreover, those who love and delight in the true Dharma are those whose initial mind desires and delights;
those who uphold the true Dharma are those whose final mind is in accord.
Entering the ranks of Dharma friends, is the correct body.
Because of upholding the Dharma, one enters the ranks of virtuous bodhisattvas, called entering the ranks of Dharma friends.
Entering the ranks of Dharma friends clarifies that the practice of protecting the Dharma is accomplished, and one will definitely attain Buddhahood, thus being prophesied by the Buddha.
World-Honored One, I see the acceptance of the true Dharma and below, this text comes with two main points:
First, the distant arising, and second, the proximate arising.
As for the distant arising, above, ÅšrÄ«mÄlÄ spoke of accepting the true Dharma, and now she looks up to the Buddha.
As for looking up to the Buddha, it shows that accepting the true Dharma has great merit and power.
Second, the proximate arising praises the Dharma-protecting bodhisattvas who accept the true Dharma for having great power, and requests the Buddha to bear witness.
The text is divided into two parts:
First, it clarifies that the Buddha has the virtue of being able to know;
Also completely knows and sees and below clarifies the Buddha's knowledge.

The Buddha is the true eye means that for such Dharma-protecting people, the merit of their transformation is vast and profound, and those on lower grounds cannot fathom it. Only the Buddha clearly illuminates it, so it is said that the Buddha is the true eye.
The five phrases such as true wisdom and so forth praise the Buddha.
It is divided into two parts:
The first two sentences, with true eyes and true wisdom, praise the Buddha's ability to know and see the function of embracing the true Dharma;
Next, there are three sentences praising the Buddha's ability to understand the Dharma.
The initial illumination is called eyes, and the later knowledge is called wisdom.
Moreover, the term eyes refers to the Buddha's eyes among the five eyes, and wisdom refers to the Buddha's wisdom among the wisdoms of the three vehicles.
All are able to accord with the realm as it is, thus called true.
Nagarjuna said:
Only the Buddha, the one person, has the Dharma of non-deception.
Therefore, among the four eyes, he takes the Buddha's eyes, and among the eleven wisdoms, he takes the wisdom of suchness.
Being the root of the Dharma means the Buddha is the origin of attaining the Dharma.
Moreover, because the Dharma comes from the Buddha, it is therefore the root of the Dharma.
Fully understanding all, it is the penetrating Dharma.
Being able to bestow the true Dharma to sentient beings, it is the support of the true Dharma.

Also know and see means that Shengman said, I see that Dharma-protecting bodhisattvas have such power. The Buddha has true eyes and true wisdom, and also knows and sees that this person has great power.

At that time the World-Honored One - previously, the extensive explanation of accepting the true Dharma had four parts. The first three chapters have already been explained. This is the fourth, rejoicing and praising.
In the text, there are two parts:
The first clarifies the TathÄgata's inner mind of rejoicing, and the second clarifies the external expression of praise.
As for great vigor, it means giving rise to myriad practices and pervading the capacities of all beings. The Dharma-stream moment by moment. This clarifies the matter of rejoicing.

Above, Shengman extensively clarified accepting and giving rise to self-benefit, giving rise to benefiting others, and abandoning the three impermanent parts to attain the three permanent parts. This is Dharma-protection, which is the power of great vigor.
Giving rise to a mind of rejoicing means following and giving rise to joy in what Shengman has said.
It also rejoices in their practice and praises their words, thus it says arises with a sympathetic mind.
There are three meanings for joy:
First, the practice accords with principle; second, the words match the capacity; third, it looks up to and praises the TathÄgata.
The mind is without fixed attachment, thus the Buddha sympathizes.
Thus, ÅšrÄ«mÄlÄ... is the second, the expression of praise and description.
The text is divided into two parts:
First, confirmation; second, praise and encouragement to practice.
The initial confirmation is to cause all sentient beings to give rise to faith.
Moreover, it wishes to accomplish the sÅ«tra.
The Buddha's words are called a sÅ«tra, while what is said by others must be confirmed by the Buddha.
Moreover, the Buddha wishes to cause beings to believe and accept without doubt, thus he must confirm it.
Like a powerful man... is the second, praising and encouraging practice.
The text has four parts:

First, using the analogy of a strong man to praise the demons, second, using the analogy of the bull king to praise the two vehicles, third, using the analogy of the mountain king to praise the bodhisattvas, and fourth, clarifying the great benefits and therefore encouraging practice.
If based on the summary, above there are four headings and four explanations, now there are four summaries.

The first summarizes the principle Dharma, the second summarizes the practice Dharma, the third summarizes the resultant Dharma, and the fourth summarizes the teaching Dharma, all clearly shown in the text.
The first has three parts:
First, the analogy; second, the combination; third, using other good things to show the superiority.
Touching a small part of the body causes great suffering for people means some people say:
It should be said that a strong man touches a small part of another's body.
It can also be said that touching a small part means slightly touching another's body and then causing great suffering.
The combined meaning clarifies that a single thought in accord with the acceptance of the true Dharma can transcend the demon realm, so the demons suffer greatly.
Some people say:
When one receives the five precepts up to leaving the household life, the yakshas hear it and pass it on to each other, up to the demon king.
When the demon king hears it, his palace trembles and he becomes frightened.
Hearing about accepting the true Dharma, he feels great suffering and is greatly frightened.

This is a small comparison to a greater extent. How much more so for one who is in accord with the true Dharma, becomes a buddha or bodhisattva, and is able to bestow the Dharma of the four vehicles upon sentient beings.
Master Fu says:
Accepting the true Dharma is considered a small acceptance of the true Dharma.

This means that simply giving rise to the aspiration to joyfully accept the true Dharma is already superior to humans and gods, truly ascending to the holy stage, and therefore its merit is incomparable.
I do not see... is the third praise compared to other wholesome [actions].
Other wholesome [actions] refer to the wholesome [actions] of ordinary beings and the two vehicles who have attained anything outside of accepting the true Dharma.
Also like the king of oxen below is the second comparison of the king of oxen to the two vehicles to praise, clarifying the meaning of the accomplishment.
The two vehicles do not accept the correct Dharma of the six pÄramitÄs, now in comparison, therefore accomplishing the above causal practices.
It is also threefold, namely combining, illustrating, and concluding.
The reason for bringing up the king of oxen is as the Lotus SÅ«tra says, using oxen, deer, and sheep to illustrate the three vehicles.
Now, clarifying the king of oxen is the great white ox of the Lotus SÅ«tra.
Its form and color are incomparable means that its characteristics are superior.

One is the arising of craving, and the other is the arising of views. Those with craving are the likes of celestial demons, and those with views are the ninety-six kinds of non-Buddhist teachings.

In the Lotus Sutra, the flow of love aroused by the heavenly demons is likened to poisonous insects, and the non-Buddhists are compared to evil ghosts. These two go against the true Dharma, so they are called evil.
When the Buddhas appear in the world, they gather these two evils and return them to the correctness of the five vehicles, which is called the gate of gathering evil and returning to correctness.

Although those who receive the teachings abandon the two evils, they cling to the five differences. Now, gathering those five differences and returning them to the same One Vehicle, it is called the gate of gathering differences and returning to sameness.
